title: The G protein α subunit Tga1 of Trichoderma atroviride is involved in chitinase formation and differential production of antifungal metabolites

items.abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>As a result of a transcriptome-wide analysis of the ascomycete<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">Trichoderma atroviride</jats:named-content>, mycoparasitism-related genes were identified; of these, 13 genes were further investigated for differential expression.<jats:italic>In silico</jats:italic>analysis of the upstream regulatory regions of these genes pointed to xylanase regulator 1 (Xyr1) as a putatively involved regulatory protein. Transcript analysis of the<jats:italic>xyr1</jats:italic>gene of<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">T. atroviride</jats:named-content>in confrontation with other fungi allowed us to determine that<jats:italic>xyr1</jats:italic>levels increased during mycoparasitism. To gain knowledge about the precise role of Xyr1 in the mycoparasitic process, the corresponding gene was deleted from the<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">T. atroviride</jats:named-content>genome. This resulted in strong reductions in the transcript levels of<jats:italic>axe1</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>swo1</jats:italic>, which encode accessory cell wall-degrading enzymes considered relevant for mycoparasitism. We also analyzed the role of Xyr1 in the<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">Trichoderma</jats:named-content>-<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">Arabidopsis</jats:named-content>interaction, finding that the plant response elicited by<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">T. atroviride</jats:named-content>is delayed if Xyr1 is missing in the fungus.</jats:p>
title: Trichoderma atroviride Transcriptional Regulator Xyr1 Supports the Induction of Systemic Resistance in Plants

items.abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>A high-throughput sequencing approach was utilized to carry out a comparative transcriptome analysis of<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">Trichoderma atroviride</jats:named-content>IMI206040 during mycoparasitic interactions with the plant-pathogenic fungus<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">Rhizoctonia solani</jats:named-content>. In this study, transcript fragments of 7,797<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">Trichoderma</jats:named-content>genes were sequenced, 175 of which were host responsive. According to the functional annotation of these genes by KOG (eukaryotic orthologous groups), the most abundant group during direct contact was “metabolism.” Quantitative reverse transcription (RT)-PCR confirmed the differential transcription of 13 genes (including<jats:italic>swo1</jats:italic>, encoding an expansin-like protein;<jats:italic>axe1</jats:italic>, coding for an acetyl xylan esterase; and homologs of genes encoding the aspartyl protease<jats:italic>papA</jats:italic>and a trypsin-like protease,<jats:italic>pra1</jats:italic>) in the presence of<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">R. solani</jats:named-content>. An additional relative gene expression analysis of these genes, conducted at different stages of mycoparasitism against<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">Botrytis cinerea</jats:named-content>and<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">Phytophthora capsici</jats:named-content>, revealed a synergistic transcription of various genes involved in cell wall degradation. The similarities in expression patterns and the occurrence of regulatory binding sites in the corresponding promoter regions suggest a possible analog regulation of these genes during the mycoparasitism of<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">T. atroviride</jats:named-content>. Furthermore, a chitin- and distance-dependent induction of<jats:italic>pra1</jats:italic>was demonstrated.</jats:p>
title: Identification of Mycoparasitism-Related Genes in Trichoderma atroviride
